central_thesis: This edition of The Scroll of Set presents a diverse collection of articles that contribute to the practical and philosophical development of Setian Initiates, emphasizing individual Xeper (self-creation), the application of magical principles in various domains (from Enochian work to visual art), and critical engagement with the broader occult and social landscape, particularly within the context of perceived societal decline and the Temple of Set's role as a 'light in the darkness' for self-reliant individuals.

structure_content.summary: A short, evocative poem celebrating Setian camaraderie and the power of 'Our kind' on blasting winds under moonlight.

Explores the Enochian Æthyrs from a Setian viewpoint, suggesting they are 'rings of consciousness' that expand inward toward the self. It describes æthyr invocation as a method for charting initiatory progress by willfully changing consciousness, where perceptions shift according to the æthyr's attributes, influencing daily life over an extended period. Ascent is sequential, automatic after ritual invocation and successful passage.

A personal invocation affirming the individual's role as a 'hero' and 'keeper of my own Black Flame'. It speaks of the Black Flame burning away humanity's dross, leading to a fraternity of like-minded individuals for forging the soul and exalting in unity/diversity. It dedicates the self to Xeper and Remanifestation using Runa, aspiring to become a god who bends the unknown to their will amidst other gods.

Details an encounter with the 'Loyalists of the Vampire Realm', an organization dedicated to preserving and recreating vampire folklore. It describes the group's structure, membership benefits (ID card, certificate, network info, newsletters), and provides contact information for those interested in joining a vampiric subculture.

A poetic invocation to a 'Dark Angel', speaking of surrendering to its bindings to achieve immortality. It references the 'ancient blood' and 'Gift of Set' as sources of genius and victory, inviting the self to careen through mastery, unchecked by logic, embracing a sacred abyss for 'Dark Grace'.

A poetic piece celebrating the process of self-transformation and growth, likened to a 'mighty fountain' and 'crystalline bird'. It invokes the 'Black Flame', 'Bat', and 'Raven' as symbols of penetrating cyclic depths and tuning to universal currents, culminating in the formation of a 'diamond consciousness' that wills forth its beauty.

Provides practical instructions for creating a glowing blue/purple pentagram using black posterboard, silver paint-pen, and fluorescent fishing line. This magical tool is designed to appear to float over an altar under black light, enhancing ritual Working.

A reflective poem about individual effort and leaving a lasting mark. The narrator, digging a waterway, contrasts his willful action with those who preach acceptance of the river as it is. It emphasizes the importance of trying and creating, naming one's creations after inspirational figures.

Outlines a methodical checklist-based procedure for active and effective reading, particularly for Setian Initiates. It covers pre-reading considerations (why, how it aids Xeper, source, applications), during-reading engagement (pursuing information, creating thought-paths), and post-reading analysis (summary, learned lessons, relevance to Setian path, future research). The system promotes intellectual Xeper and critical engagement with texts.

Presents a fabricated occult text, 'The Pickman Codex', as a framework for studying 'LBM (Left-Brain Magic?) techniques in visual art'. It details methods for 'capture', 'detention', and 'securing' an audience's attention and influencing them emotionally, physiologically, and intellectually through color and form. It summarizes the biological, psychological, and cultural effects of various colors for practical application in visual magic.

Announces a new 'Editorial Arena' section for Setians to engage in Socratic discourse on initiatory topics. The first topic questions the viability and propagation of 'Runa' as the 'archetypical mystery articulated' and its successful incorporation into individual initiation, inviting arguments for or against its efficacy and meaning.

structure_content.chapter_title: Palaces of Memory: Scattered Ramblings of Priest Barrett on a Hot Summer Night in Baltimore with No One Around to Talk To!
structure_content.summary: A philosophical exploration of the mind-brain relationship, inspired by the idea that culture biologically affects brain architecture. It discusses the material basis of the psyche, drawing on observations of brain-damaged patients, and posits a reciprocal relationship between mind and matter. The author connects this to 'memory palaces' and Xeper, seeking to understand how to build a 'better, stronger, faster psyche' by willfully modulating consciousness.

structure_content.chapter_title: Interview with the Founder of the Church of Satan
structure_content.summary: An interview with Edward M. Webber, identified as an Honorary Member of the Temple of Set, who claims to have originated the idea of the Church of Satan. Webber disputes Anton LaVey's narratives regarding the Church's founding, LaVey's belief in Satan, his claims about Marilyn Monroe and Jayne Mansfield, and the initial organizational structure, providing an alternative historical account.

A reprinted news article detailing the growth of new religious movements and New Age spirituality in Europe, citing declining church attendance, the fall of communism, and a search for spiritual alternatives. It highlights Europe as a 'growth market' for these movements, with roots in European occultism and a changing worldview shifting from Christian teaching to Westernized Buddhism and Hinduism.

Analyzes the current 'disordered climate' characterized by disintegrating traditional controls, 'negative civilization', and the 'Spirit of Moloch'. It discusses the implications for the Temple of Set, advocating for a lower public profile, selective responses to attacks, and a focus on Setians using the Temple as a tool for individual Xeper rather than a 'substitute god'. It also addresses 'Metareligion' and the global nature of higher human consciousness, encouraging Setians to embrace their individualism and global reach.

key_concepts.definition: Conceptualized not as external quadrants, but as 'rings of consciousness' that expand inward toward the self. Invoking an æthyr induces a 'vision' where perceptions align with its attributes, influencing the Initiate's consciousness over time to chart initiatory progress. Ascent is a willful act of changing consciousness, sequential and automatic once an æthyr is ritually passed.

A central concept in Setian philosophy, representing the individual's unique self-awareness and potential for Xeper. It is described as burning away 'dross of humanity', leading to understanding and self-exaltation. Nurturing one's Black Flame is key to individual and collective growth within the Temple of Set.

The core Setian principle of self-creation, self-evolution, or 'to come into being'. It is the driving force behind individual initiation and the application of magical tools. The articles emphasize Xeper through diverse practices, from Æthyr work to critical reading and conscious manipulation of perception.

Referred to as the 'archetypical mystery articulated' and a tool for 'personal Xeper and Remanifestation'. Its viability and successful incorporation into individual initiation are presented as a topic for Socratic discourse, suggesting its significance as a Setian magical concept.

A term used within the context of 'The Pickman Codex' to refer to techniques in visual art intended to influence an audience. This involves a three-stage process: 'capture' (gaining attention), 'detain' (holding interest), and 'secure' (long-lasting influence). Color and form are identified as core elements, with detailed analyses of their biological, psychological, and cultural effects.

Mental connections or ideas generated from reading material that an Initiate wills themselves to follow up on later. This concept emphasizes active engagement with texts and integrates 'Will into reading' as a component of intellectual development and magical practice within the Setian system.

A term used to describe a contemporary societal climate characterized by 'negative civilization', the disintegration of traditional controls, mass apathy, cynicism, and a regression towards brutish, drastic social discipline (e.g., jingoistic imperialism, witch-hunts). The Temple of Set positions itself as a 'light in the darkness' amidst this environment.

Refers to the supranationalizing of higher human consciousness, extending beyond traditional religious structures and cultural barriers. It describes a global spiritual trend where people seek alternatives to enslaving religious or ideological systems, aligning with the idea that the 'Gift of Set' burns in minds worldwide, leading them to various forms of self-exercise.

practical_system.description: The text presents several practical systems and methodologies. Daniel S. Ayres II°'s 'On the Æthyrs' describes a practical system for using Enochian Æthyrs as a tool for self-initiation, focusing on conscious ascent and charting personal progress. Elizabeth Reynolds II° details a clear, inexpensive method for constructing a visually impactful pentagram for ritual use. David J. Hohl I°'s 'The Pickman Codex' outlines an 'LBM' system for visual magic, detailing how to 'capture', 'detain', and 'secure' an audience's attention and influence through conscious manipulation of color and form, based on biological, psychological, and cultural effects. Rosemary Webb II° provides a practical checklist for critical reading as a method for intellectual Xeper and skill improvement.
tools: Enochian system and its associated tables for Æthyr work.
Pencil, heavy black posterboard, silver medium-tip paint-pen, straight-edge, compass, sewing needle, 4-strand 8-lb fluorescent fishing line, and tape for pentagram construction.
Knowledge of color psychology, biology, and cultural associations for visual magic applications.
Checklists and structured questions for active, critical reading and information synthesis.
rituals: Ritual invocation of Enochian Æthyrs for conscious ascent and initiatory progress.
Construction and use of an 'electrifying pentagram' for enhancing ritual workings under black light.

relevant_quotes.text: I find the æthyrs to be an effective method of charting my progress in initiation. Further experimentation by interested Setians will provide more insights into these powerful and effective magical tools.
I am the hero of my life, the keeper of my own Black Flame. This Flame has burned the dross of humanity from my eyes, revealing things to me hidden to the sleepwalking masses.
For what is a god but a human who is awake, aware, and unfearing of the unknown that calls out to the universe and bends it to his will? I am a god in the company of gods; my will be done!

O Dark Angel, loosen the fabric woven of time. Surrender its bindings about you to fall at your feet before me. I come to you through the shadows of your own thirsting soul; I am remembrance of the ancient blood that is the Gift of Set in you. I am ordained to raise your dark, silken wings to the height of immortality, the folly of time to span and conquer.
Color has the power to influence muscle tension, heart rate, breathing, and other physiological processes of the human body.
The Temple of Set for the 1990s CE is going to be what it was intended to be in 1975 CE: a tool for each and every Initiate. The Temple should never be considered something around which you orbit.

But this entire development emphasizes what the Temple of Set has been talking about for the last few years: the supranationalizing of higher human consciousness. Like it or not, we have to stop thinking about the Temple as a North American enterprise and conceptualize it as symbolic of a quality in higher humanity which exists around the entire planet.

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue of The Scroll of Set is highly relevant for Setian Initiates and practitioners of Western Esotericism. It provides practical methodologies for magical work (Enochian Æthyrs, visual magic, ritual tool construction) grounded in Setian philosophy, particularly Xeper. The philosophical discussions on the mind-brain relationship, the nature of Runa, and the critical analysis of the contemporary 'Spirit of Moloch' foster intellectual growth and contextualize Setian practice within broader societal trends. The historical insights into the Church of Satan offer a critical perspective on modern occult movements. Overall, the content serves to equip Initiates with diverse tools and perspectives for self-development and magical engagement with their world.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is Initiates of the Temple of Set, particularly those seeking practical methods for advancing their Xeper, engaging in philosophical and magical discourse, and understanding the organizational history and contemporary role of Setianism. It also appeals to practitioners of Western Esotericism and Occultism interested in Enochian magic, visual magic, consciousness studies, and the historical development of modern occult organizations, especially given the critical historical review of the Church of Satan.
